metadata.description: Systems Engineering Qualification Planning Tool - Complete Learning Objectives with Full Text Content
metadata.verification: Values verified against Marcel Niemeyer's Master Thesis Table 4-2 (page 67)

competencies.name: Lifecycle Consideration
competencies.originalName: Consideration of system life cycle phases

Systems Thinking.1: The participant knows the interrelationships of their system and the associated system boundaries.
Systems Thinking.2: The participant understands the interaction of the individual components that make up the system.
Systems Thinking.4: The participant is able to analyze his existing system and derive continuous improvements from it. The participant is also able to establish system thinking among colleagues.
Systems Thinking.6: The participant is able to bring systems thinking into the company and inspire others to do the same. In addition, the participant can independently define or at least question the system limits/scope.

Systems Modelling and Analysis.1: Participants know the basis of modeling and its benefits.
Systems Modelling and Analysis.2: Participants understand how models support their work. They are able to read models easily.
Systems Modelling and Analysis.4: Participants are able to independently define their own system models for their relevant scope. They can also correctly classify and understand various models.
Systems Modelling and Analysis.6: Participants can set guidelines for (necessary) models and write guidelines for good modeling.

Lifecycle Consideration.1: Participants know the life cycle phases of their system
Lifecycle Consideration.2: The participant understands why and how all life cycle phases must be considered in the context of development or application of the system.
Lifecycle Consideration.4: The participant is able to identify, consider and evaluate all life cycle phases for the scopes relevant to him.
Lifecycle Consideration.6: The participant is able to evaluate concepts with regard to the consideration of all life cycle phases, identify weaknesses in the methodology and make suggestions for improvement.

Customer / Value Orientation.1: The participant recognizes the basic principles of agile thinking.
Customer / Value Orientation.2: The participant understands how agile thinking can be integrated into everyday working life
Customer / Value Orientation.4: The participant is able to develop a system according to agile thinking and to put the customer benefit in the foreground.
Customer / Value Orientation.6: The participant is able to bring agile thinking into the company and inspire others to do the same. In addition, the participant can independently define agile methods for the projects.

Requirements Definition.1:
Process: Participants can differentiate between requirements, stakeholder requirements, system requirements and sub-system requirements and understand their interactions.
Method: The participants know the different processes of requirements management and are able to derive user/customer requirements.
Tool: The participant knows how to create a requirements table.
Requirements Definition.2:
Process: Participants understand how requirements sources are identified, how requirements are derived from sources, and how the requirements of a system are passed on to the subsystem.
Method: Participants know and understand how and when which requirements formats are used efficiently. (Text vs. spreadsheet vs. database)
Tool: Participants can easily read requirements in a database.
Requirements Definition.4:
Process: Participants can independently identify sources of requirements, derive requirements from them, and transfer system requirements to subsystem requirements.
Method: Participants are able to formulate requirements correctly (e.g. "good criteria") and to find an efficient methodology for eliciting requirements.
Tool: The participants are able to create, edit and extend requirements in a requirements database independently.
Requirements Definition.6:
Process: Participants are able to recognize shortcomings in the process and develop suggestions for improvement. He is able to guide and evaluate the requirements processes.
Method: The participant is able to use and introduce all relevant requirements methods in the company and to guide colleagues in the formulation of requirements.
Tool: Participants are able to bring requirements tools into the enterprise and guide colleagues in setting up requirements in the tool. He is also able to introduce new tools or improve existing ones.

System Architecting.1:
Process: The participants know the purpose of architecture models. They can roughly categorize them and understand which problems they solve.
Method: The participant knows the various processes of system architecture (logical and physical architectures).
Tool: The participants know SysML and are able to understand simple representations.
System Architecting.2:
Process: Participants can understand why architecture models are relevant as inputs and outputs of the process step and why the architecture is relevant as a design guideline for the system.
Method: The participant understands the various processes of system architecture (logical and physical architectures). He is able to derive the architecture of a system from its requirements.
Tool: The participants can read and understand SysML notations.
System Architecting.4:
Process: Participants know the relevant process steps for architecture models and know where their inputs come from and where the outputs must go. Participants are able to understand architecture development at system and subsystem level.
Method: The participant is able to independently develop a system architecture. The system architecture is traceable from the requirements.
Tool: The participants are able to build various SysML diagrams themselves.
System Architecting.6:
Process: Participants are able to recognize shortcomings in the process and develop suggestions for improvement.
Method: The participant is able to use and introduce all relevant architecture development methods in the company.
Tool: The participants are able to set up and/or optimize the toolchain for system modeling in the company.

Integration, Verification, Validation.1: The participant knows the objectives of verification and validation and knows different types and procedures.
Integration, Verification, Validation.2: The participant can read and understand test plans, test cases and test results.
Integration, Verification, Validation.4: The participant can create test plans. They will be able to carry out and document tests and simulations.
Integration, Verification, Validation.6: The participant is able to set up a test strategy and a test plan independently and at an early stage and to document the test planning. He is also able to plan and conduct design reviews.

Operation and Support.1: The participants know the lines of the operation, service and maintenance phase. They know that these are of great importance for the project.
Operation and Support.2: Participants understand how the operation, service and maintenance phases are taken into account in the development of a system. You understand the need for redundancy in the design.
Operation and Support.4: Participants understand how the operation, service and maintenance phases are taken into account in the development of a system. The participant is able to develop concepts and systems that ensure the availability of the system.
Operation and Support.6: Participants will be able to define the organizational processes for operations, service and maintenance and place them in the context of the entire life cycle.

Agile Methods.1: Method: The participant knows the agile values and the relevant agile methods
Agile Methods.2: Method: The participant understands the basics of agile working methods and how agile methods can be used in his work.
Agile Methods.4: Method: the participant can work in an agile environment. He is able to apply the necessary methods.
Agile Methods.6: The participant can define and implement the relevant agile methods for a project. The participant is able to teach and introduce agile methods to others in the company.

Self-Organization.1: Participants are familiar with the concepts of self-organization.
Self-Organization.2: Participants understand how the concepts of self-organization influence their everyday work
Self-Organization.4: Participants are able to work on projects, processes and tasks in a self-organized manner.
Self-Organization.6: Participants are able to work on projects, processes and tasks in a self-organized manner.

Communication.1: Participants know the necessity of these skills
Communication.2: Participant recognizes and understands the relevance of this competence, especially with regard to the optimal functioning of his team.
Communication.4: Participants are able to communicate constructively and efficiently and at the same time be empathetic to the needs and ideas of their colleagues. They are able to cooperate in interdisciplinary teams. The participant is able to challenge and be challenged and see it as their strength.
Communication.6: Participant is also able to manage their relationships with colleagues and superiors in a sustainable manner. The participant is able to resolve conflicts, bring different perspectives together, negotiate sustainable compromises and thus also lead groups.

Leadership.1: Participants know the necessity of these skills
Leadership.2: Participant understands the relevance of defining goals for a system and can define them in a way that benefits the team.
Leadership.4: Participant is able to negotiate goals with the team and find an efficient way to achieve them.
Leadership.6: Participant is able to strategically develop team members so that they continue to develop when finding solutions.

Project Management.1: Process: The participant is familiar with thematic field project management and can organize their activities according to it.
Project Management.2: Process: The participant understands the project assignment and can categorize project management into the overall procedure. The participant is able to work in a project according to the standards and create the relevant outputs.
Project Management.4: Process & Method: The participant is able to define a project assignment and set framework conditions. He is able to take control of the project team and guide them in achieving the project objectives. The participant is able to apply the relevant project management methods.
Project Management.6:
Process: The participant is able to identify shortcomings in the process and make suggestions for improvement.
Method: The participant is able to use and introduce all relevant project management methods in the company.

Decision Management.1: Participants know the main decision-making bodies and how decisions are made
Decision Management.2: Participants learn about decision support methods and understand which decisions they can make themselves and which they must delegate
Decision Management.4: Participants are able to prepare decisions for their relevant scopes or make them themselves and document the decision-making process accordingly.
Decision Management.6: Participants can evaluate decisions and are able to define and establish overarching decision-making processes that facilitate traceable and sustainable decisions.

Information Management.1: The participant knows the advantages of established information and knowledge management.
Information Management.2: The participant knows the main platforms for knowledge transfer and knows which information needs to be documented.
Information Management.4: The participant knows the main platforms for knowledge transfer. They are able to define filing structures for the project. He is able to maintain and provide project information independently.
Information Management.6: The participant can define a comprehensive information management process.

Configuration Management.1:
process. The participant understands the necessity of configuration management
Tool: The participant knows the principle of version control and understands configuration control.
Configuration Management.2:
Process: The participant understands the procedure for defining configuration items. He is able to read and understand configurations defined by others.
Tool: The participant is able to read version histories. The participant is able to create configurations/baselines.
Configuration Management.4:
Process: The participant can define meaningful configuration items. He is able to recognize the configuration items relevant to him. The participant can carry out changes to the configuration under controlled conditions.
Tool: The participant is able to set up version control for their project.
Configuration Management.6:
Process: He is able to recognize all relevant configuration items and build an integer configuration with them. The participant is able to establish the topic in the company and to take over guidance.
Tool: The participant is able to set up the relevant tool landscape for configuration management in the company.

dataStructure.step1: Identify the qualification archetype/strategy for the company
dataStructure.step2: For each competency, look up the target level in 'archetypeCompetencyTargetLevels'
dataStructure.step3: Retrieve the corresponding learning objective text from 'learningObjectiveTemplates'
dataStructure.step4: Use RAG LLM to customize the standard objective based on company context

lookupProcess: 2. learningObjectiveTemplates['Decision Management']['4'] = 'Participants are able to prepare decisions...'
3. Feed to RAG LLM with company PMT context for customization

ragLLMInput.expectedOutput: Company-specific learning objective adapted to their context
